Award.AwardTitle: Controls on the carbon isotopic composition of coalbed biogenic methane and implications for biogas stimulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. David Vinson has been awarded an NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship to implement a research and education program based at Northwestern University. He will investigate stable carbon isotope signatures imparted during methanogenic biodegradation of coal. Natural abundance carbon stable isotope (13C/12C) ratios are valuable signatures of specific pathways and processes associated with methanogenesis. Yet, interpretive uncertainties and discrepancies with microbiological techniques complicate the use of carbon isotopes to diagnose methanogenic pathways of interest (e.g. acetoclastic methanogenesis and CO2 reduction). Other competing biogeochemical processes - in particular sulfate reduction - and mass balance effects may also influence observed carbon isotope signatures. Additional pathway-specific tools and techniques may improve understanding of the utilization of methane precursors, especially acetate. The primary tasks of the research are to adapt methods of analyzing compound-specific and intramolecular carbon isotope ratios of acetate to the low concentrations encountered in microbial gas systems, to analyze these isotope ratios in waters from natural and laboratory-constructed methanogenic systems in order to trace acetate utilization during methanogenesis, and to apply modeling techniques including reactive transport modeling to the mass balance of methanogenic coal biodegradation.

Natural gas is an increasingly important energy resource, of which a significant portion is of biogenic origin. The research focuses on microbial methane derived from unmined coal (coalbed methane), and has implications for naturally-occurring and human-stimulated biogas resources derived from other carbon sources. In order to stimulate the native microbial community to yield additional methane, a detailed understanding of natural processes and pathways is required. In this research, the use of a compound-specific isotope tracer technique will promote understanding of the utilization of acetate in methanogenesis or in competing processes that do not yield methane. In other words, the efficiency of natural or modified methane-producing systems may be recorded by the isotope signature of acetate, combined with information on source organic carbon and end products (methane and CO2). Education and outreach activities associated with the postdoctoral fellowship include developing and conducting a biofuels-related summer workshop for K 12 teachers and involving undergraduate students in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The postdoctoral fellowship supported early-career scientist David Vinson in a program of research and education focused on biogenic gas, and specifically on the natural-abundance stable isotopes of carbon (carbon-13/carbon-12 ratios) in biogenic gas. In the postdoctoral fellowship, Vinson was mentored by sponsoring scientist Neal Blair of Northwestern University.

Biogenic gas is derived from microbial activity in the subsurface, which degrades organic matter in the absence of oxygen to yield methane and carbon dioxide. This process of methanogenesis causes relatively large changes to the carbon-13/carbon-12 ratio, leaving methane depleted in the heavier isotope carbon-13 relative to the source organic matter. Recent studies suggest that carbon isotopes, hydrogen isotopes, and microbial community characterization techniques can yield inconsistent interpretations of microbial activity and methanogenesis in coal beds. This complicates the use of established isotopic fingerprinting techniques, such as the carbon-13/carbon-12 ratio of methane. The overall objective of the project was to improve our understanding of what carbon isotopes record in biogenic coalbed gas systems. More specifically, the project sought to: (1) address inconsistencies in widely-utilized isotope fingerprinting techniques; (2) evaluate the potential for competition between methanogenic and non-methanogenic processes such as sulfate reduction; and (3) to apply a compound-specific isotope approach to coal beds, targeted at acetate. Acetate is utilized by one metabolic pathway of methanogenesis, which consumes acetate and imparts a carbon isotope effect on the residual unreacted acetate.

This project supported field sampling of biogenic gas basins in the United States, in which gas and water were collected from producing wells. The project also included a one-year laboratory incubation in which methane and acetate were monitored during the conversion of coal to methane. For compound-specific acetate isotope analysis, acetate was preconcentrated and extracted from water samples, then analyzed by gas chromatography - isotope ratio mass spectrometry at Northwestern University. Compound-specific isotope ratios of acetate were analyzed and reported from three biogenic gas basins and the laboratory incubation. The considerable range of carbon-13/carbon-12 ratios of acetate observed during this study suggests a possible, but variable, role for the acetoclastic pathway of methanogenesis in coal beds. This result deepens our understanding of coal beds from previous isotopic studies that imply methanogenesis is dominated by a separate pathway that consumes hydrogen and carbon dioxide. When used in combination with other isotope data (such as carbon isotopes of methane and carbon dioxide), the compound-specific isotope results from the Powder River Basin suggest that both methanogenesis and non-methanogenic pathways (e.g. sulfate reduction) may compete for organic substrates such as acetate.

To date, the postdoctoral fellowship has supported Vinson's role in two published peer-reviewed journal articles. As of this report, one additional article supported by the fellowship is in revisions after undergoing peer review.

This research has potential implications for energy resources, as an estimated 20% of natural gas resources worldwide are biogenic. In many coal beds hosting biogenic methane, the microorganisms responsible for methanogenesis apparently remain active today.

Broader impacts of the postdoctoral fellowship include two workshops on methane biogeochemistry and biogas for high school science teachers, co-led by Vinson at Northwestern University.
